text: thank you all for coming today to First the AWS Chicago Summit 2016 really
appreciate you all coming in from everywhere that people came in from for this event my name is Chris muns I'm the
development I'm the business development manager of devops here at AWS based in our New York City office so I traveled
in for this as well and today we're going be talking about continuous delivery uh this is part of our devops
on AWS uh kind of theme that we have here through a number of our talks earlier in January did a webinar
infrastructure as code we have this talk here that we're doing at a number of our Summits this year and we'll be
continuing to add more and more into the space around devops at AWS and how you
can make use of our tools and services and understand some of the culture that we have here at
AWS so why are we here today you know continuous delivery is a big topic today in the software development world uh
something that is not necessarily new but something that I feel many more companies are paying attention to
especially with with the rise of things such as Agile development methodologies devops and general the cloud driving
companies to look to move faster when it comes to developing their applications for uh wherever their applications might
be living and the reality of it is is that software development moves a lot faster today than it used to right
startups can now take on industry Giants with little to no upfront investment uh they have access to their users as well
as to infrastructure in ways that they've never had access to before and so the ability to get your application
or your code or your project whatever is that you want to call it into the hands of millions of people is greatly simplified compared to how it was even
five years or so ago and what this means for established organizations is that your ability to fight off this
disruption is tied directly to how quickly you can react and so Enterprises are not known as organizations that can
move quickly and react quickly to disruption and this is especially true when it comes to software development
however not thinking about these things is a very dangerous thing to not be aware of we talk about how drastically the model
has changed it was only just a couple of years ago where when you wanted to go and buy software for your PC that sat
somewhere under a desk of your home at your home involved you getting in your car driving to a store like this one
walking up and down the aisles of really cool gizmos and gadgets you went and touched all the computers I know I did
and looked at all the stuff that I wish I could buy to find that box buy it drive it home install it and you did
this with software on a very small frequency however we think about how devices today
are being reached out to you know the App Store only came about in the last 10 years a little less than that I think it
was 2009 officially or 2008 that the App Store first launched today what you have is the ability to write apps publish
them and you know maybe just a couple of days or hours even potentially worth of time and have it immediately available
on an online store that millions of people around the world can get access to it while they're sitting on the
toilet at home no need to get up put on pants get in your car car drive to the store walk up and down touch all the
things find the box and reverse that so you know the delivery model has completely changed and it's shrunk into
things like watches we've got cars that now have app stores coming out we've got devices like the Echo and so you've got
a completely different software distribution model than you had just a couple of years ago and releasing
software in this world requires different tools you can't do this using the old waterfall methodology you'll
never be able to keep up with again the disruptors that you're facing in the world today and so there are tools that
we need things to help us manage the flow of our development tools to help us properly test our code and make sure
that we're building some level of quality assurance into it and then things to tools to eventually deploy our
applications out so number of different tools that exist in this space that we have to think about but it also would
help us to know a little bit about the process or I like to reflect back on the you know the old Dunkin Donuts
commercial with the guy that would say time to make the donuts I like to equate software development application
development to making donuts because at the end of the day if you're doing it really well should be at a very high
velocity and the changes should look very boring should be very basic you should be crafting out these doughnuts
that look the same time after time versus building one doughnut that's 3 feet wide and one doughnut that's 2 in
wide and one doughnut that's chocolate and one dut that's strawberry they should all look and feel the same over
time and it's these tools and practices that lend it to becoming much more of a at the end of the day mediocre process
really it should be the code actually getting out there that should be the thing that generates the excitement so
if we think about release processes we at AWS feel that there are four major phases that represent those so there's
the source phase where you are writing your code potentially getting it reviewed and then you commit it into some sort of you know revision control
tool there's the build phase where depending on the language of your application and where it's destined uh
maybe you're compiling it maybe you're just doing unit tests maybe you're building a container maybe you're doing something further with it uh but
typically a very important part of your application development there's tests where you're taking this a step further
and in the uh case of code that ends up living on a server somewhere that is either a web service an API based
service you know a UI based web service something like that where you're going to be doing integration with other tests
databases other services that you talk to you need to do things like load testing UI testing penetration testing
potentially lots of different things that you could think of you know today we announced public availability for
inspector this is the kind of phase where inspector would fit into things and then lastly there's our actual
production deployment right whether this is putting code out into an ec2 instance into Lambda into a container running an
ECS or into a mobile app that's sitting in s some sort of app store we want to get this out in front of where other
people can consume this thing we also think about how you work through these different uh process
stages as having levels so one that many people are familiar with is continuous integration this is the concept of on
every commit your code is going up to some centralized place and then getting tested and potentially you know built
depending on again the language that you're using taking this one step further is the concept of continuous
delivery this idea that after this initial build and test this code is ready to be deployed out to some
environment doesn't necessarily need to be production all the way but it is some environment that could then be consumed
by either other testing Frameworks development team QA team what have you and then typically there's some sort of
a gate or some sort of an action that needs to take place in order for that last mile push out to production to
happen and then lastly there's this concept of continuous deployment this is the idea that on every commit all of the
above is going to happen and code is going to go out to production so it's important to understand the differences
between these three I think often people mix up these three different uh levels
if you will as the same thing so when people talk about CI and CD they're typically talking about continuous
delivery not continuous deployment though continuous deployment should be the eventual goal that you're aiming for
in any organization and so today's focus is really around this middle one which is
continuous delivery so we're going to make the assumption that every time we commit code it's being built and tested
however we're going to potentially say that code doesn't have to go out to production every time because there may be extra work that we have to manually
do before that's ready so lots of benefits to continuous delivery huge benefit around automating
the deployment delivery process right we want to make our delivery process look like stamping out the donuts versus
building a unique individual doughnut every single time right make it become a very boring thing actually at the end of
the day and this allows us to improve developer productivity right if we're removing a lot of the uniqueness from this process and it becomes more
standardized then it makes developers be able to not have to think about all the unique cases that are involved in every
time they're writing their code and then releasing it in a less frequent process which also allows us to find and address
bugs more quickly if we're running through a barrage of tests on every commit or every couple commits or
whatever it might be then we're much more likely to find bugs and errors than if we wait until a nightly build or a
weekly build or something like that and then lastly this allows us to deler updates much quickly much more quickly
so if we're finding these bugs and we're addressing them and we're doing performance testing we're going through all of the steps involved we can get out
to production a lot quicker than if we were doing these things manually or not doing these things as
often so here in Amazon we actually have some interesting stories about how we've done this internally and how we've
shifted so you know youall are here today hearing what we have at AWS and thinking you know what an exciting
Cutting Edge creative kind of a company relative is we have a lot of attributes that make us like a large Enterprise
like you would see anywhere else going back a little bit historically here in 2001 if you ever shopped on amazon.com
you were interfacing with a large monolithic Pearl application when you opened up
amazon.com you landed on that landing page you went to a category page you searched for an item you went to a
listing page you added it to a cart you did checkout all of that was one huge monolithic application that was
maintained by one huge development team one huge it team and all the kind of
pain that comes along with having not too many cooks in the same kitchen but too many cooks stirring the same pot
everyone adding their own ingredients everyone adding their own little bits of flavor and at the end of the day the goulash didn't taste too good so what we
realized is that we had to really change this and so starting in 2001 we made a drastic change in the organization both
in terms of the people and the technology to shift to what today people would consider micro services so that's
kind of this this fun little ball diagram that we have here of all the interconnected points as well as something that we call two Pizza teams
so this is a very big topic that we could spend an entire day talking on but essentially two Pizza teams is the idea that any team working on a problem is no
bigger than that which could be fed by two pizzas at lunch typically it works out to be about six to 10 people working
on a single problem and so this has really changed the way that we build and run our application if you go to
amazon.com today and you look at a listing page you're actually seeing data brought forward to you from dozens of
different Services all the little various aspects about what else you could buy recommendation similar items
other buyers or other sellers I should say price points all these kind of things are bubbled up from different
services and what you end up seeing basically is the result of the display service calling those forward and it was
very much this move to this type of a structure what let us do this so again that started in 2001 and we talked a
little bit there about the endstate in 2009 and so things were working a lot better in this again right we were able
to move much faster teams were able to work in parallel so it gave us a much more increased velocity in terms of how
we were able to get code out however we thought that we could do better we thought that there could be even more
room for improvement and so back in 2009 we ran a study across all the development teams on Amazon to find out
where they were spending their time and where there might be inefficiencies that might still exist that we can help squeak out and what we found is that
even though we had these teams that were working in parallel and were much more agile than they had been eight years
prior what we had was a lot of waiting so team would write their code they'd
have to wait for a build Fleet to be available they'd have to wait till it uh was able to be deployed to a test
environment and then they would do that deploy to production typically because this was being done by different teams
or different tools that had to be interfaced with by different teams and so where as the actual activities that
we were doing would take just minutes it was this waiting period this handoff that was incredibly painful it's
actually a really great story by a gentleman named Phil kakato out of SoundCloud he wrote a blog post back in September about how SoundCloud realized
this very similar thing they had a multi-on release cycle that they realized that a majority of the time was
just waiting for someone to read a ticket read an email read a message and then do some work and so this whole
process here had us spending weeks of time for what should have been very simple releases again the actual work
was just minutes whereas the weight was days or hours and so we wanted to do was shrink this entire process down such
that the waiting period was pretty much gone and what we had were people committing actions and then very quickly
The Next Step happening such we could shrink this process down entirely to just be
ours so we built a number of tools inside of Amazon to help make this happened one of the biggest tools that
we built to solve this was one that was called pipelines so pipelines is a pretty interesting tool it's a
continuous delivery tool that allows you to automate from checkin to production the entirety of a workflow involved with
uh developing software with everything being automated in between so from checkin to build to test to the deploys
to very I integration environments that deploys to production with all the you know governance and controls that we
would need to have exist in a mature responsible type of an environment so there were lots of benefits to this well
it helped us shrink our time periods down a lot so we got much faster it also got a lot safer to deploy once we had
all of this automated so by working to automate the entire process we removed a lot of some of the human factors that
might happen that would potentially change things it also offered up ability
for us to get some simplification standardization in terms of how we did things which was really important as we
brought in new developers or as developers may be moved from Team to team being able to have every developer
in the company know that pipelines is the tool to handle continuous delivery means that when you go to look at
another team's pipeline regardless of what it is that they have going on in that pipeline you can very easily GP and
understand what it is that's going on in their delivery process and then lastly this was a visual tool so that was a key
component of it was the ability to visualize where in the delivery process you were and then be able to again
understand where in the flow things were happening so pipelines was pretty successful for us and if we take just a
single data point about this from 2014 across all of the thousands of service teams that we have at Amazon that are
building these micro services that are practicing continuous delivery across
the many environments that we have what it means is that in 2014 we did 50 million deployments that
year so 50 million deployments is about a deploy less than every 1 second
typically out to 10 or more hosts someplace globally in our infrastructure and this is without there being some
sort of central coordination team or Central sign off this is all these teams acting independently and so this is a
pretty awesome velocity to have again these teams are deploying very rapidly as they need to but there were other
really interesting benefits to this so we regularly do these studies internally about developer happiness and what
they're see seeing is making them more successful and what they see is making them more happy and what is making them
drive better product inside of Amazon and so also in 2014 this study told us
that statistically the only tool that we had that could be statistically tied to happier developers was this pipelines
tool and it was this aspect around continuous delivery that made these developers happier because we were
reducing the friction for them to get code from their fingertips into their keyboards out to the potentially
millions of users that that service or that application or that API might be consumed by so this is a really
interesting fact it I've never seen anything else in the industry that could talk to statistical knowledge of people
being happier because of continuous delivery as well as being largely more
successful so this past summer in summer of 2015 we released AWS code pipeline
which is essentially the the AWS ification of this internal pipelines tool so something that you all could
start using right now today and so it's a continuous delivery service that allows for fast and reliable application
updates allows you to model and visualize your software release process it allows you to you know automate the
builds testing and deployment of your code across basically any platform that you could think of and then it
integrates with third party tools and other AWS services and actually you can build custom Integrations which we'll
talk about here in a little bit and so benefits lists are pretty pretty easy to realize right a configurable workflow so
any application that you're developing no matter what it is could make use of pipe of code pipelines uh very easy to
integrate we'll see some Integrations here in a little bit based on the fact that you're automating the process you get improved quality rapid de delivery
and then lastly we make it really easy to get started so we'll dive in here a little bit into how code pipeline looks
and how it works what I have here is an example of a code Pipeline and we'll go over some of the terminology that we
have with this so this is a pipeline pretty straightforward pipelines are made up of
stages stages are then made up of actions stages are connected to each
other via transition and so that's kind of the
basics for this right so what you see here is a three-stage pipeline each stage has a single action and then there
are you know individual transitions between those interesting things we can do with code pipeline though is that we
can also run parallel actions and then we can also do
sequential actions so what this allows us to do potentially is in our Dev and
test uh process maybe there's things that we want to do at the same time maybe we want to run our code through
static analysis tool we want to run it through a tool like inspector we want to run it through a code coverage tool we
could actually have all three of those things happen at the same time and have all three of those things be a failure
gate to determine if we move forward so if any of those fail we're going to stop this process
instead of having these happen in parallel where really the three might be of equal importance to each other and
then going back to the concept of sequential there are times when you would want one thing to happen after another so the great thing is here again
with code pipeline is that this is ready to model however it is that you want to around whatever your workflow might
be so let's dive a little bit further into what it looks like to work in this
model so I'm a developer I've written some code I'm a horrible developer though but that's just just me so I've
taken my codee I've committed it to GitHub so I've committed to GitHub I've hit enter on git push it's now gone up
there and lives up there in GitHub behind the scenes code pipeline it's pulling GitHub looking for changes so it
sees that there's a change it's going to take that change it's going to bring it down and put it into S3 as an artifact
for me so now I have my code taken put into this artifact and S3 so let's say
that I happen to have a Java application so it needs to be built for me so it has to go through a compile stage
so I'm all done with my source stage now I'm going to go down to my build stage so it's going to transition onto that
next one via code pipeline in this case somewhere I have a Jenkins host up and running that Jenkins host has an agent

job so it acknowledges it then goes and grabs my source does it work it needs to do and then puts a built artifact back

some sort of code in a compiled language Jenkins can toss it back on the other side Jenkins says I'm all done here code
pipeline moves forward to the next step the next step for me here is using elastic bean stock to do a deploy so
code pipeline goes and tells elastic beanock here's the artifact that you're looking for passes it on to beanock and
then beanock handles the deploy for me of this application with whatever means it is that I've configured bean stock to
use so in this example oops in this example code pipeline hasn't done any of
the actions itself involved of this code all right it's not the source control
repository it's not the Builder it's not the artifact storage it's not the deployment engine in fact what I've done

orchestration that's been automated from the developer perspective I hit get push
and then I was done I had to sit back and wait for this to finish so that maybe then I can go and do some manual
QA or continue on forward with what it is that I had to do and so the friction from the developers perspective is
incredibly low so we have a number of partners that we interface with today and we're always

build where do you start with this so I often find companies that are doing no testing of their code before they ship

then also a lot of people staring at their feet and so that typically tells me that there'd be usually double the amount of hands that I would expect so
where do you start so my advice is start really really basic right find a linter for your language and make sure that
you're not missing things like commas and brackets and quotes really super basic level to get started just to make
sure that your code would actually run or compile you know from there you might want to think about working forward from
the user interface aspect back down towards the code level so you know if it's a web- based application are your
pages even rendering properly um is it as an API is it actually starting as a
server backend whatever that might be and then move on to deeper checks and
then lastly you want to think about unit testing which again is something that I find is done at very
very very little of it done I should say in most organizations this is typically where you want to spend the most of your
time and so there are a number of books where they talk about in C and CD and a number of articles that you'll find well they'll reference the testing pyramid
and the testing pyramid starts with unit testing as a foundation moves up to service or integration testing and then
lastly ends with UI testing and so in this case typically you want to spend
the amount of time around the testing at these levels about 70% of your testing should fall under unit about 20% at
service and about 10% of UI and so there's a lot of studies that go into discussing this in terms of the
effectiveness of this testing where the benefits pay out where you're more likely to catch bugs where you're less
likely to catch bugs but generally speaking you want to think about investing your time in this

quick okay so when it comes to deploying your applications in code pipeline we've got Integrations again with code deploy
and elastic being stock so code deploy if you're not familiar with it is a service that is uh exists for the sole
purpose of moving bits onto hosts essentially it's an agent based service agent runs in Linux or Windows it's
completely language agnostic but one of the key things about how code deploy works and what its goals is is to
support uh zero downtime rolling deployments um basically to help you
during a deployment obviously not have any impact to your end users due to that
deployment you can use this on Prem off Prem or sorry on AWS or off AWS uh and
again this also integrates with a number of third party tools so the agent that runs on your host is looking for an
instruction file to exist inside of your code repository and this is called an appec
yml file so the aspect yml file has a number of different sections to it that help basically tell the agent what it
should do on your host we don't see deployments being just move the bits from my repo to a host we see that move
the bits from a repo to my host and then set permissions on it maybe run a script to start or stop a server or my like my
application server maybe run a script to add a remove from an elb maybe I actually want some part of my app to go
in one directory and then I want to put conf configuration files in a different part and so what code deploy allows you
to do is basically model this throughout your deploy so we see here is an example
of the file section where I just have uh a single source and single destination but I could have multiples of these I
also have permissions that I'm setting pretty straightforward here so that my web app could potentially be accessed and then down at the bottom
here these hook section this is where I can run scripts to do basically anything that I want so there are five different
life cycle hook events that we support uh you see here application stop before install there's an after install
application start and then validate service validate service is probably one of the most important ones that you
could have in validate service you're typically going to run uh a script that would look similar to a health check
from say a load Bal balancer this is basically a way for the code deploy agent to tell the back end that the
deploy has been successful and so again you can think of this as a way to say that your application is healthy maybe
you have an application that's jvm based that you need to pre-warm and you need to wait until there's some sort of acceptable performance from it this is a
great way that you could use a validate script to kind of kick off that preor of that application to get it up and responding
properly so I mentioned that code deploy supports the capability for zero downtime deployments one of the ways
that it does that is around giving you the ability to select a speed at which you go through a pool of hosts so given
here an example where I have six hosts I have the option of doing one at a time half at a time all at once essentially
any uh integer or percentage based roll out that I'd want to do through these and you get to select this when you're
setting up your deployment groups one of the other great things about code deploy is how it has the ability for me to
specify what I'm targeting a deploy towards so we call these deployment groups pretty straightforward and we
give you the ability to Target either autoscaling groups or instances based on tag now if you do auto scaling groups
one of the nice benefits to this is that when a new host comes up in an autoscaling group code deploy the agent
on it will be checking the back end we'll see that there should be a deploy on this host and it will deploy the most recent deploy to that pool so this is
another great way to automate the ability for autoscaling hosts to get your application on it without you say
having to bake an Ami or use some sort of outof band configuration management tool and we really Envision you using
this the same way across the environment so if you have a Dev environment that's two hosts in a prod environment that's
however many it might be we envision you having the same appec file for both of these and then being able to make use of
either variables based on the deployment group or some sort of other identifier to potentially configure them differently if

forms of inter abilities to integrate with code pipeline the first is this
concept of custom actions so the way the custom actions work is that you have a piece of software out somewhere that is
going to be looking for work from codee pipeline so in this case we've got an agent that's running somewhere it's
going to be pulling code pipeline for work when it sees a job it's going to acknowledge it it's going to perform
that task and then it's going to put success afterwards and in this case pretty straightforward this is the way
that the Jenkins plugin works with code pipeline this basic kind of four-step process the other way that we can
interface with code pipeline or integrate with it is via Lambda so the Lambda flow is a little bit different than the custom action flow is in this
case we've got our Lambda function and out there is Lambda when we get to this action in our code
pipeline code pipeline actually does the invocation of the Lambda function so code pipeline reaches out invokes Lambda
